Class RonPST

All Implemented Interfaces:
com.davidsoergel.dsutils.GenericFactoryAware, com.davidsoergel.dsutils.Labellable<String>, com.davidsoergel.stats.MutableDistribution, edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.AdditiveClusterable<RonPST>, edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.Clusterable<RonPST>, SequenceSpectrum<RonPST>, Cloneable
public class RonPST
extends RonPSTNode
implements SequenceSpectrum<RonPST>, com.davidsoergel.stats.MutableDistribution

A probabilistic suffix tree, as described in

D. Ron, Y. Singer and N. Tishby. The power of amnesia: learning probabilistic automata with variable memory length. Machine Learning, 25:117-149, 1996. http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/article/ron96power.html

Version:

David Soergel

completionProcessor

public com.davidsoergel.stats.DistributionProcessor<RonPST> completionProcessor
Constructor Detail

RonPST

public RonPST()

RonPST

public RonPST(double branchAbsoluteMin,
              double branchConditionalMin,
              double pRatioMinMax,
              int l_max,
              SequenceSpectrum prob)
Constructs a new Probabilistic Suffix Tree according to the Learn-PST algorithm (Ron et al 1996 p. 13), based on an existing sequence spectrum (typically, the set of all word counts; or naively just the sequence itself, if we don't mind re-scanning it a whole bunch of times as they seem to suggest).

Parameters:
branchAbsoluteMin - the minimum total probability of a string that should be taken seriously. Branches with probabilities less than this will be pruned. Ron et al. call this pMin.
branchConditionalMin - the minimum conditional probability of a symbol that we are interested in. Ron et al. express this as (1 + alpha) * gammaMin. Here we just provide it directly since the smoothing process (and hence gammaMin) are broken out.
pRatioMinMax - The ratio threshold for considering the probability of a symbol to have changed compared to the back-off prior. That is, either the symbol probability must be a factor of pRatioMinMax greater than its back-off prior value, or vice versa, in order for the probability to be taken seriously. Note that values less than 1 would cause all symbol probabilities to pass the test, so those aren't very useful.
l_max - the maximum depth of the tree (that is, the maximum memory length)
prob - the SequenceSpectrum providing the symbol conditional probabilities from which the PST will be learned
Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException - if something goes wrong with the given spectrum

Description copied from interface: SequenceSpectrum
Returns the length of the sequence that was scanned to produce this spectrum. This number may be greater than that given by #getNumberOfSamples() because every symbol is not necessarily counted as a sample, depending on the implementation.

public double conditionalProbability(byte sigma,
                                     byte[] prefix)
                              throws SequenceSpectrumException
Computes the conditional probability of generating a symbol given a prefix under the model, backing off to shorter prefixes as needed if the given prefix is not explicitly represented.

Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException - when anything goes wrong

fragmentLogProbability

public double fragmentLogProbability(SequenceFragment sequenceFragment,
                                     boolean perSample)
                              throws SequenceSpectrumException
Computes the total log probability of generating the given sequence fragment under the model. This differs from totalProbability(byte[]) in that the sequence fragment is not given explicitly but only as metadata. Thus its probability may be computed from summary statistics that are already available in the given SequenceFragment rather than from the raw sequence. Also, because these probabilities are typically very small, the result is returned in log space (indeed implementations will likely compute them in log space).

Specified by:
fragmentLogProbability in interface SequenceSpectrum<RonPST>
Parameters:
sequenceFragment - the SequenceFragment whose probability is to be computed
perSample - normalize the probability by the number of samples found in the SequenceFragment, i.e., take the geometric mean
Returns:
the natural logarithm of the conditional probability (a double value between 0 and 1, inclusive)
Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException

setIgnoreEdges

public void setIgnoreEdges(boolean b)
Specify whether or not this sequence spectrum attempts to account for edge effects, i.e. the first and last words of each sequence. Accounting for these properly introduces a good deal of complexity and requires extra time, so considering spectra to describe biases is infinitely long sequn

Specified by:

setImmutable

public void setImmutable()
Declare that this spectrum should not change anymore. In practice this is not enforced; this is used only to free up memory by forgetting data that would be needed to recompute the spectrum if it were to change.

Specified by:
setImmutable in interface SequenceSpectrum<RonPST>

spectrumEquals

public boolean spectrumEquals(SequenceSpectrum spectrum)
Test whether the given sequence statistics are equivalent to this one. Differs from equals() in that implementations of this interface may contain additional state which make them not strictly equal; here we're only interested in whether they're equal as far as this interface is concerned.

Naive implementations will simply test for exact equality; more sophisticated implementations ought to use a more rigorous idea of "statistically equivalent", though in that case we'll probabably need to provide more parameters, such as a p-value threshold to use. Note that the spectra know the number of samples used to generate them, so at least that's covered.

Specified by:
spectrumEquals in interface SequenceSpectrum<RonPST>
Parameters:
spectrum - the SequenceSpectrum to compare
Returns:
True if the spectra are equivalent, false otherwise
